Main_Event_Assessment_With_Annotation: Typhoon Dot, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Saling, was the strongest storm of the 1985 season. Dot originated from a small area of thunderstorm activity in early to mid October. The system was first classified on October 11, and steadily intensified over the next few days. Dot attained typhoon strength on October 15, and subsequently entered a period of explosive deepening, which was not anticipated by forecasters.

Total_Summary_Death.Total_Death_Annotation: In all, Dot was responsible for 90 deaths and $104.9 million (1985 USD) in damage.

Total_Death_Per_Country.Death_with_annotation: Throughout the Philippines, 24 people were hurt, and 88 perished, and over 1 million people were directly affected.
After passing the Philippines, Typhoon Dot skirted Hainan Island, leaving two dead.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Death.Death_with_annotation: In Davao Del Sur, 10 people were killed and several homes were destroyed due to mudslides.
A man was swept away in a landslide in Legaspi, which also forced the evacuation of 165 families.
Offshore, three people were killed and 16 others were rendered missing when a cargo ship sunk.
Seven fatalities occurred in Cabanatuan, where 2,500 homes were demolished and 22,000 were damaged.
After passing the Philippines, Typhoon Dot skirted Hainan Island, leaving two dead.

Location_with_Annotation.Philippines: Although damage across the Philippines was less than initially expected, the typhoon lashed the nation with heavy rains.
Location_with_Annotation.Nueva Ecija: Province of Nueva Ecija suffered the worst effects from Dot. There, 500,000 acres (200,000 ha) of crops and 90% of all buildings were damaged.
Location_with_Annotation.Cabanatuan: In Cabanatuan, 2,500 homes and 90% of structures were destroyed.
Location_with_Annotation.Manila: Flooding in low-lying areas of Manila forced the evacuation of 29,000.
Location_with_Annotation.Davao Del Sur: In Davao Del Sur, 10 people were killed and several homes were destroyed due to mudslides.
Location_with_Annotation.Legaspi: A man was swept away in a landslide in Legaspi, which also forced the evacuation of 165 families.
Location_with_Annotation.Pampanga: Elsewhere, 69,000 houses were flooded in Pampanga, Tarlac, and Nueva Ecija.
Location_with_Annotation.Tarlac: Elsewhere, 69,000 houses were flooded in Pampanga, Tarlac, and Nueva Ecija.
Location_with_Annotation.Hainan Island: While tracking through the South China Sea, Dot passed through Hainan Island. There, two casualties occurred while 34 others suffered injuries.
Location_with_Annotation.Sanya: Communications were lost in Sanya, the southernmost city in the island.
Location_with_Annotation.Vietnam: On October 21, Dot struck Vietnam while still a typhoon, but dissipated the next day over the high terrain of the nation.

Total_Summary_Damage.Total_Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_an: In all, Dot was responsible for 90 deaths and $104.9 million (1985 USD) in damage.

Total_Economic_Damage_Per_Country.Total_Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_an: Throughout the Philippines, 24 people were hurt, and 88 perished, and over 1 million people were directly affected. Nationwide, damage totaled $104.9 million.

Typhoon Dot skirted Hainan Island, leaving two dead. Communications were lost in Sanya, the southernmost city in the island. Thirty-four were hurt. A total of 50,000 homes and 83,000 acres of farmland were flooded. More than 2,300 houses also collapsed.
Early on October 21, Dot moved ashore in northern Vietnam, around 240 km (150 mi) south of Hanoi. Land interaction with the high terrain of the nation resulted in rapid weakening.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Economic_D.Economic_Damage_Assessment_with_annotati: The worst effects of the storm were felt in Nueva. There, 202,345 ha (500,000 acres) of crops and 90% of all buildings were damaged, totaling to $5.3 million (1985 USD).
Seven fatalities occurred in Cabanatuan, where 2,500 homes were demolished and 22,000 were damaged. Ninety percent of all infrastructure was destroyed.
Flooding in low-lying areas of Manila forced the evacuation of 29,000.
Elsewhere, 69,000 houses were flooded in Pampanga, Tarlac, and Nueva Ecija.
Communications were lost in Sanya, the southernmost city in the island.
A total of 50,000 homes and 83,000 acres of farmland were flooded. More than 2,300 houses also collapsed.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Wind: Typhoon Dot, known in the Philippines as Typhoon Saling, was the strongest storm of the 1985 season. Dot attained typhoon strength on October 15, and subsequently entered a period of explosive deepening... Dot attained its maximum intensity... Dot struck Vietnam while still a typhoon.

Perils_Assessment_With_Annotation.Landslide: In Davao Del Sur, 10 people were killed and several homes were destroyed due to mudslides. A man was swept away in a landslide in Legaspi.

In Cabanatuan, 2,500 homes were demolished and 22,000 were damaged. Ninety percent of all infrastructure was destroyed.

Total_Summary_Affected.Total_Affected_Annotation: Throughout the Philippines, 24 people were hurt, and 88 perished, and over 1 million people were directly affected.

Total_Affected_Per_Country.Affected_with_annotation: Throughout the Philippines, 24 people were hurt, and 88 perished, and over 1 million people were directly affected.

After passing the Philippines, Typhoon Dot skirted Hainan Island, leaving two dead. Communications were lost in Sanya, the southernmost city in the island. Thirty-four were hurt. A total of 50,000 homes and 83,000 acres of farmland were flooded. More than 2,300 houses also collapsed.

Early on October 21, Dot moved ashore in northern Vietnam, around 240 km (150 mi) south of Hanoi. Land interaction with the high terrain of the nation resulted in rapid weakening, and by 0000 UTC October 22, the JTWC ceased tracking Dot.

Specific_Instance_Per_Country_Affected.Affected_with_annotation: In all, 42 towns were flooded, which forced a total of 125,000 people to flee their homes, 35,000 of which were homeless.
Seven fatalities occurred in Cabanatuan, where 2,500 homes were demolished and 22,000 were damaged. Ninety percent of all infrastructure was destroyed.
Flooding in low-lying areas of Manila forced the evacuation of 29,000.
Elsewhere, 69,000 houses were flooded in Pampanga, Tarlac, and Nueva Ecija.
After passing the Philippines, Typhoon Dot skirted Hainan Island, leaving two dead. Communications were lost in Sanya, the southernmost city in the island.
Thirty-four were hurt. A total of 50,000 homes and 83,000 acres of farmland were flooded. More than 2,300 houses also collapsed.
